title: Identifying Low-Pressure Weather Fronts
brief: How to recognize approaching low-pressure fronts that bring extended bad weather.
steps: Step 1: Notice slow-moving or nearly imperceptible winds combined with heavy, humid air.
Step 2: 'Smell' the front - sluggish, humid air makes wilderness odors more pronounced than normal.
Step 3: 'Hear' the front - sounds become sharper and carry farther in low-pressure conditions.
Step 4: Prepare for bad weather that will likely persist for several days.
Step 5: Secure shelter and gather supplies before the front fully arrives.
warnings: Low-pressure fronts often bring extended periods of bad weather lasting several days.
The combination of humidity and barometric changes can affect human health and energy levels.
